content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would consider this to be a repeated game of the prisoner's dilemma with slightly different payoffs. In each round, cooperating (picking R) yields a higher reward for both players when they both choose the same action, but there is also a risk of getting nothing if one chooses R while the other chooses B.

Since we don't know our opponent's strategy, it's hard to make a definitive choice. However, we can analyze our potential payoffs based on our own strategy.

1. If I play R and my opponent plays R: I get 45$ every time
2. If I play R and my opponent plays B: I get 0$ every time
3. If I play B and my opponent plays R: I get 40$ every time
4. If I play B and my opponent plays B: I get 20$ every time

In a one-shot game, it seems logical to choose B since it guarantees a higher average payoff (20$) compared to choosing R (expected value of 15$). However, in this repeated game scenario, cooperation (choosing R) becomes more attractive because both players can build trust and maximize their total earnings over the long run.

Assuming my opponent is rational like me, they might reason similarly about their choices. If we both choose to cooperate most of the time, we will benefit from the higher payoff of 45$ per round for as many rounds as we both stick with R. On average, choosing R will yield a higher long-term payoff compared to sticking with B, even though it involves some risk of getting nothing if the opponent switches to B.

Therefore, I would choose R to cooperate and build trust with my opponent over time, hoping for mutual cooperation that maximizes our total earnings in the 75 rounds. My choice: {R}
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, I chose R, and my opponent also chose R in the first round, so we both received a payoff of 45$. Since we are rational agents seeking to maximize our earnings over the long run, it makes sense for us to continue cooperating (choosing R) as long as our opponent does the same.
